emails.snippet: Hi Matthew Thank you responding to my email. In order to hire you what I have do what kind of documents I have to sign also I would like to know how much I pay in order to retain you, please let me
emails.body:
Hi Matthew
Thank you responding to my email. In order to hire you what I have do what kind of documents I have to sign also I would like to know how much I pay in order to retain you, please let me know.
Thank you
Marjan
Sent from my iPhone

On Feb 9, 2026, at 5:40‚ÄØPM, Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca> wrote:

Ôªø
Hi Marjan

In a nutshell, these are some of the initial questions we would conclusively answer once we start working.

I can tell you now that: you purchased the shares. The sales agreement has a number of relevant provisions. Your friend is right that asking for the employment contracts is one specific next step.

I'm obligated to say that the above is not legal advice. I cannot provide legal advice or act as your business' lawyer until there is an agreement between us.

Best regards


Matthew AJ Levine
Barrister & Solicitor

This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.



On Mon, Feb 9, 2026 at 3:22‚ÄØPM marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>> wrote:
That is email I want to share with you
Sent from my iPhone

Begin forwarded message:

From: Kristi Kanitz <kristi@flagshipsoftware.com<mailto:kristi@flagshipsoftware.com>>
Date: February 7, 2026 at 12:29:26‚ÄØPM EST
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>>
Subject: Questions to ask the lawyer:

Ôªø 1. Did you purchase the shares of the business or the assets?

2. What does the sale agreement say about the current employees?

Find out from the previous owner:  Did the current people that work there sign employment contracts? If so, where are the contracts?

3. Should you have the current employees sign new employment agreements? If so, what consideration should be offered (you have to give them something to get them to sign)? Keep in mind that even signing the new agreement doesn't mean they start a probationary period.

Find out how long each of the employees has been there. That will tell you what kind of severance you will be responsible for if you decide to terminate them.

Kristi

--

General Manager

Kristi@flagshipsoftware.com <mailto:Kristi@flagshipsoftware.com>
www.flagshipsoftware.com <https://www.flagshipsoftware.com/>

emails.snippet: Hi Laura Thanks. As reviewed on the other thread, what is realistic is that I can assign and review your work. We would start off working on files where the firm has some financial security from the
emails.body:
Hi Laura

Thanks.  As reviewed on the other thread, what is realistic is that I can
assign and review your work. We would start off working on files where the
firm has some financial security from the client. We would work together on
those files to deliver for the clients.  Then, over time, my goal would be
to identify specific scopes where it makes sense for you to work directly
with the client, tho I would still be available to discuss the file with
you and review your work.

How about Wednesday at 4 or 4.30?

Best regards

Matthew


*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor


This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.

emails.snippet: Hi Lino thanks! overall, i think we are getting into the parts of the 'master workflow' that have become hard to standardize and delegate. its like: there is a frame that mostly makes sense Hi
emails.body:
Hi Lino

thanks!

overall, i think we are getting into the parts of the 'master workflow' 
that have become hard to standardize and delegate. its like: there is a 
frame that mostly makes sense



Hi Matthew, 

1. That makes sense I was thinking whoever needs to create the task can do 
it under the section but I agree user-wise that would create unnecessary 
work when they can just pick it from the field. I can absolutely create 
that automation! 

lets give it a try

2. Asana doesn't have an automation where the subtasks change based on the 
section the task is moved into. We can do this: 
- *Option 1:* We create one task template per section (each with its own 
subtasks) and set a rule that when task is moved to Section X ‚Üí Convert 
task to Template X. However, this overwrites the task with the template and 
it will delete the comments, attachments, or custom progress.

- *Option 2:* We create one master task, have all possible subtasks once 
(as we have now), group subtasks by color or prefix: 

üü¶ - Onboarding 
üü© - Opening 
üü® - Maintenance 

Sample subtask: 

üü¶ DRAFT: Engagement Agreement
üü¶ CONFIRM: Engagement Agreement Stored in Clio

3. Sorry abt this, I thought whoever's handling Intake has their own board. 
Let me know if this is something that we need in the future!

Kindly let me know your thoughts. Thanks! 



*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor

emails.snippet: Hi Max I have a draft. I think it would be good for you to review and then we can consider next steps. I don't have a preference with regards to mediation/arbitration. My preference is what is best
emails.body:
Hi Max

I have a draft. I think it would be good for you to review and then we can 
consider next steps.


I don‚Äôt have a preference with regards to mediation/arbitration. My 
preference is what is best for me. I always imagined that this document 
would be air tight and not require?

 

fundamentally, each party is entitled to dispute resolution. i do agree 
that arbitration only is preferable.



I don‚Äôt think it will be in my interest to negotiate. I would be interested 
in it, as long as it could only be triggered by me.

agreed. I prefer to focus on finality. if the two of you genuinely decide 
and agree to revisit / renegotiate that is always possible.


The most relevant provisions are 8 and 10. Especially 8(b) and 8(e). 8(b) 
sets out the baseline deal of 1.5% "dividend". 8(e) sets out the right to 
the house if you walk away from the relationship. The challenge is that 
8(e) is about property but the terms that you are seeking to achieve uses 
the property as support. 


In Ontario family law, property and support are seen as two distinct silos.

   1. 
   
   *Property silo*
   - 
      
      Ownership, equalization, tracing, constructive/resulting trust
      - 
      
      Governed primarily by the Family Law Act (Part I) and equity
      - 
      
      Less difficult to contract out of
      2. 
   
   *Support silo*
   - 
      
      Compensatory, non-compensatory, needs-based support
      - 
      
      Governed by Divorce Act / Family Law Act
      - 
      
      Only partially contractable; always subject to residual judicial 
      supervision. 
      

A family lawyer would recommend to use the cohab to coordinate but not 
blend property and support.

the terms we started off with used property as a substitute for support, 
and in doing so collapsed the silos. 

There are two principal examples:


   - Property used as satisfaction of support via the ‚ÄúEnhanced Settlement 
   Amount"
   - Support indexed to corporate economics because the agreement ties 
   periodic spousal support to Mascore‚Äôs distributable income. 





3. Why ‚Äúcross-contamination‚Äù is the right term 

Calling this ‚Äúcross-contamination‚Äù is not rhetorical; it is analytically 
accurate.

Once property is used as support:

   - 
   
   property waivers are no longer cleanly severable from support provisions;
   - 
   
   courts are more willing to reopen property consequences when varying 
   support; and
   - 
   
   the agreement loses the normal insulation where ‚Äúproperty survives, 
   support fails.‚Äù
   
In other words, the client‚Äôs instinct (use property to satisfy support) is 
understandable, but the execution *weakens both sides of the contract*.
------------------------------
4. The client‚Äôs objective vs. the legal risk 

The client‚Äôs objective appears to be:

   - 
   
   avoid long-term cash-flow support exposure;
   - 
   
   cap downside risk on relationship breakdown; and
   - 
   
   use hard assets (house equity) as a release valve.
   
That objective is legitimate.

The problem is *where* it is being implemented.

Doing this inside the *support silo* invites:

   - 
   
   unconscionability analysis;
   - 
   
   fault scrutiny; and
   - 
   
   judicial re-characterization.
   


*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor


This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and 
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message 
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.

> To: Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
>
>  
>
> Hi Max
>
>  
>
> I am giving this serious thought.
>
>  
>
> Lets pls consider one big picture issue: what if any thoughts do you have 
> about potentially selling Mascore. 
>
>  
>
> Just looking at your draft. It covers the shares but it does not cover the 
> potential capital gains. 
>
>  
>
> We can draft to include the dividends and the capital gains. But, this 
> raises the next question, which is why I am bringing this up:
>
>  
>
> What if any plans do you have about structuring the shares so that you 
> have a tax strategy for potential capital gains. The "rub" is that one of 
> the potential tax strategies is to put shares in a trust for Amber and your 
> kids (but one of the goals of the cohabitation is to keep the shares out of 
> a deemed trust / family trust) . Then their access to the lifetime capital 
> gains exemption can also be used, in the event of a sale.
>
>  
>
> I did not know that the company had done so well this year.  
>
>  
>
> More concretely
>
>    - I will work on preparing a draft.
>    - you are not married, but are you (actively) planning to get married? 
>    - is the urgency that you are looking to get married, or is it more 
>    that you have managed to have a productive conversation about a difficult 
>    topic and now want to get this sorted as quickly as possible?
>
>  
>
> here are my working notes, you are welcome to tell me if anything is off 
> the mark
>
>
> https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HVgUP18IcmlGvfjJecypv4dL7W7VoEM8HbO_dnCFByc/edit?tab=t.0

>
>  
>
>  
>
>  
>

Read our latest newsletter!
͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌  ͏‌ 
View web version
 
Investing insights and lessons learned, just in time to help you plan for the new year.

Hit the ground running with market insights for the year ahead! Learn about common cognitive biases, practical ways to navigate finances across generations, and how stock lending can help you earn additional income on securities you already own.

Plan with perspective: Market insights for 2026
As we kick off 2026, David Sykes, Senior Vice President and Chief Investment Officer, TD Asset Management, leads the conversation on what could be on the horizon for the markets following the ups and downs of the last year.
Listen now
 

My top 5 investing tips for a TFSA, RRSP & FHSA

Dan Kent from Stocktrades offers his top investing tips for these registered accounts, just in time for new contribution room available at the start of the year.
Watch now
 

What is stock lending‚Äîand are you doing it right now?

You‚Äôve probably heard the phrase, ‚Äúmake money while you sleep‚Ä¶‚Äù With the TD Direct Investing Stock Lending Income Program, that‚Äôs not just a saying‚Äîit‚Äôs something you and your portfolio can actually do.
Watch now

How our brains can make us bad investors

Cognitive biases can nudge us toward certain behaviours without us even realizing it. In this video, we‚Äôll explore common cognitive biases, how they could impact our investing decisions, and what we should know to help us become better investors.
Watch now

Let‚Äôs talk money: A practical guide for families
Money often plays a key role across different generations‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs parents supporting their children through major life milestones, adults helping aging parents, or siblings navigating the complexities of an inheritance. We explore why open and honest conversations about finances are so important.
Read more

Additional resources for you.
Looking for more DIY investor support?
Follow our TD Direct Investing Instagram account.
Elevate your investing IQ and subscribe to our TD Direct Investing YouTube channel.
See how you’re trending with other self-directed investors using the TD Direct Investing Index.
Need to access your account statements?
You can find them in WebBroker.
Need account or platform answers fast?
Visit our help centre.
Contact Us  |  Privacy and Security  |  Legal
 
Safeguarding our customers' information is a fundamental principle of TD Bank Group. For security reasons, certain information including account number has been masked. TD will not ask you to provide personal information or login information, such as username, passwords, PINs, IdentificationPlus® security questions and answers or account numbers, through unsolicited email. TD will not share sensitive data through regular email nor will TD request this type of information be sent from you through regular email. If you suspect an email to be fraudulent, please forward a copy to us at phishing@td.com and then delete the email.

TD Direct Investing is a division of TD Waterhouse Canada Inc., a subsidiary of The Toronto‑Dominion Bank. TD Waterhouse Canada Inc. ‚Äì Member of the Canadian Investor Protection Fund.

® The TD logo and other TD trademarks are the property of The Toronto‑Dominion Bank or its subsidiaries.

 
You have received this email at matthew@levinelegal.ca because you are a client of TD Direct Investing. To ensure delivery to your inbox (and not to your junk or bulk mail folders), add email@e.email-td.com to your address book.

If you wish to stop receiving commercial electronic messages from TD Direct Investing, please unsubscribe or go to the following web address: td.com/tddirectinvestingunsubscribe.

Please do not reply to this email ‚Äì this mailbox is not monitored.

Toronto, Ontario

emails.snippet: Hi Matthew Thanks for letting me know,,yes please ASAP.Sadly,,lot of bills are waiting to be paid.Whatever works the fastest.Just a suggestion,you can send a certified check by UPS,or I can pick it up,
emails.body:
Hi Matthew

Thanks for letting me know,,yes please ASAP.Sadly,,lot of bills are waiting to be paid.Whatever works the fastest.Just a suggestion,you can send a certified check by UPS,or I can pick it up, but of course I will wait to hear what your options are and we will go from there.Again hope to hear something from you ASAP..
Matthew,I would also like to say, I apologize for my impatience..

Thanks

Zeljko

Sent from my Huawei phone


-------- Original message --------
From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
Date: Mon., Feb. 9, 2026, 3:07 p.m.
To: Zelko Culibrk <zeeculibrk@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: 1716867 Ontario Inc. - Shareholders
Hi Zeljko

It appears that there was an issue with BMO (my bank) and the payment did not get processed. The funds remain in my trust account. I will follow up about our options for getting the funds to you. 


Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor


This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.  




On Mon, Feb 9, 2026 at 2:37‚ÄØPM Zelko Culibrk <zeeculibrk@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi Matthew 

Just quickly, just talked to the bank,,they said they have not received, or see any transfer of funds into my account.Hopefully you can check on your end, to see if there was an error made, concerning the transfer of the funds.
    I'm sure it's all fine, and like you said it might take a day or two, for the transfer to happen,,,but also it's good to double check..As soon as the funds have been deposited into my account,I will let you know.

Thanks 

Zeljko 

On Mon., Feb. 9, 2026, 12:48 p.m. Zelko Culibrk <zeeculibrk@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi Matthew 

Just wanted to let you know the funds have not been deposited into my account yet.
    The RBC financial advisor just emailed me, to let me know, the funds are not there yet.We had a meeting at 1-00.. 
     Hopefully the funds will come later today or tomorrow.I will keep you posted,and let you know as soon as the funds have been deposited into my account.

Thanks 

Zeljko 
    

On Fri., Feb. 6, 2026, 4:44 p.m. Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca> wrote:
Hi Zeljko

I am confirming that the funds have been sent. It may not arrive today but please let me know when it does arrive.

Ill follow up next week and yes we will discuss the capital gains. 


Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor


This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.  




On Thu, Feb 5, 2026 at 3:54‚ÄØPM Zelko Culibrk <zeeculibrk@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi Matthew,

Thank you for the great news.
Please let me know once the funds have been transfered.Attached is the information you need.

Looking forward to discussing the other matters (capital gains) once this it's all done.

Talk soon. Thank you,
Zeljko

Sent from my Huawei phone


-------- Original message --------
From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
Date: Thu., Feb. 5, 2026, 2:51 p.m.
To: Zelko Culibrk <zeeculibrk@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: 1716867 Ontario Inc. - Shareholders
Hi Zeljko

I have received the funds. I will transfer them to you. 

Please give me your bank account info. Also, pls share a copy of your drivers license for my records.  

Best regards
Matthew

Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor


This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.  




On Fri, Jan 30, 2026 at 12:35‚ÄØAM Zelko Culibrk <zeeculibrk@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi Matthew

Thanks for the update..The important thing for us is,, that she and her lawyer know that we accept her offer,, and you confirmed that's been done..Now I guess we have to wait for her lawyer, hopefully not for long.
If Mr.Rogers is unavailable to close the deal,, hopefully one of his coligs ,another lawyer,can finish this.We don't want to wait long either, she gave us 4-5 days and wanted a quick response,,we did that..All side's want to finish this,hopefully,ASAP, and move on.There is not much left to do,we agreed to the offer,we signed the papers, and now the only thing left is the transfer of the funds to us, that's it,I think .
Matthew, as soon as you hear something, please let us know.
Thanks
Zeljko

Resources to Help You Sell Successfully

Selling a business takes more than just a listing. These free resources are here to help you prepare your sale and market your business with confidence.

Guide to Selling Your Business

Want to dive deep? This guide includes essential steps and toolkits to navigate your sale.

Access the guide here

BizWorth Calculator

Wondering what your business is worth? Get a quick estimate in minutes.

Try the BizWorth calculator

 

Business Benchmark

See how your business stacks up against others with this quick snapshot.

Get your benchmark

Video Center

Prefer to watch and learn? Our video series explains the selling process in a clear and visual way.

Visit the Video Center

No matter where you are in your selling journey, these resources can help you get the maximum value for your business.
Need help from an expert?

You can connect with experienced business brokers on BizBuySell. From marketing to managing paperwork and buyer conversations, a broker helps streamline the process while you keep running your business.
Visit The Learning Center

Everything you need to sell with confidence.

 

Questions? We're here to help.

Contact us at (888) 777-9893 Monday - Friday (8 AM EST to 8 PM EST), or email membership@bizbuysell.com.

emails.snippet: That is email I want to share with you Sent from my iPhone Begin forwarded message: From: Kristi Kanitz <kristi@flagshipsoftware.com> Date: February 7, 2026 at 12:29:26 PM EST To: marjan
emails.body:
That is email I want to share with you
Sent from my iPhone

Begin forwarded message:

From: Kristi Kanitz <kristi@flagshipsoftware.com>
Date: February 7, 2026 at 12:29:26‚ÄØPM EST
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>
Subject: Questions to ask the lawyer:

Ôªø 1. Did you purchase the shares of the business or the assets?

2. What does the sale agreement say about the current employees?

Find out from the previous owner:  Did the current people that work there sign employment contracts? If so, where are the contracts?

3. Should you have the current employees sign new employment agreements? If so, what consideration should be offered (you have to give them something to get them to sign)? Keep in mind that even signing the new agreement doesn't mean they start a probationary period.

Find out how long each of the employees has been there. That will tell you what kind of severance you will be responsible for if you decide to terminate them.

Kristi

--
[Flagship Software Logo]        Kristi Kanitz
General Manager

Kristi@flagshipsoftware.com <mailto:Kristi@flagshipsoftware.com>
www.flagshipsoftware.com <https://www.flagshipsoftware.com/>

416‚Äë410‚Äë6357 / 1‚Äë866‚Äë672‚Äë0007 ext 102

Hi Matthew
I hope you are doing well I am so confused to know what I do with this woman we want to find a solution with out paying her but I don‚Äôt know if that is possible in the  mean time Allen worry about she have good relationships with previous owners and she goes around to bad mouth us and cause problems. We are really in very bad places want to fire her but we try to do it smart way.  I don‚Äôt know if is any smart way.
So in mean time I talk with my  friend she have business she send me emails I would like to share it with you she ask me to ask lawyer those questions.
Thank you
Marjan

On Feb 6, 2026, at 10:19‚ÄØAM, Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca<mailto:matthew@levinelegal.ca>> wrote:

Ôªø
Hi Marjan

My recommended approach is to

  *   investigate and identify how the business came to be responsible for this woman;
  *   work with you to finalize and implement replacing her; and,
  *   determine whether some or all of the costs can be recuperated from the former business owner.

The standard process is that my firm will collect a trust deposit.

I can talk this afternoon at, say, 2 or 3 pm. Do either of those times work for you?


Matthew AJ Levine
Barrister & Solicitor

On Fri, Feb 6, 2026 at 10:03‚ÄØAM marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>> wrote:
Please let me know any advice you can give me what is right thing to do.
Thank you

On Feb 5, 2026, at 9:17‚ÄØPM, marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>> wrote:

Ôªø
Hello
We did the 70,000 franchise fee as payment for the franchise. While we where looking for a site his Growing minds became for sale and the owner of the franchise said it would be good to take Growing minds and change it to Uptown Montessori under the franchise name. I believed him and he did all the disclosure and discover on his end. The Supervisor was running the day to day operations and was told I needed to keep her and the staff they had. A week after we toke over we she demanded a big raise from 60k a year 5 days a week to almost 70k a year only working 4 days a week. She was holding all the information that ran the business and I was informed to take her deal and then find a way to get her out rhe door in a few months. Right now I do not feel welcome their and I do not want to even show up. I know on paper it's my business but to me it feels like it's hers not mine
Marjan



Sent from Outlook<http://aka.ms/weboutlook>

________________________________
From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca<mailto:matthew@levinelegal.ca>>
Sent: February 5, 2026 11:09 AM
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>>
Subject: Re: Corporate Law Firm

Hi Marjan

Good day. I have the FDD, thank you.

At a preliminary level, I have questions about how the transaction was structured, particularly in relation to the franchise agreement that was entered into and the fee that was paid. To start with, can you confirm whether a $70,000 initial franchise fee was paid, and whether you were given an explanation at the time for why the transaction was treated as a new franchise rather than a transfer or change of control?

Before I can assess whether there is a legal issue to be examined, it would be helpful to make sure I understand the situation from your perspective. In particular:

  *   What concern or issue prompted you to reach out now?

  *   Who was responsible for day-to-day management of the business at the time of the transaction, and how was that role described to you?

  *   Were you told that any individual‚Äôs continued involvement was expected or required when the deal was completed?

The reason I ask is that issues involving disclosure and transaction structure are treated differently from operational or personnel disputes, and I want to be clear on the factual background.

Once I have that context, we can discuss whether there is a legal issue worth pursuing and what the appropriate next steps might be.

Best regards



Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

I don‚Äôt know you received the documents  you miss, I am more than happy to send it again, but one person I want to get her out her name is Shannon Groop and her name is not in document. I don‚Äôt want that she be there I want to know what is best opportunity that be helping me.
Thank you

From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca<mailto:matthew@levinelegal.ca>>
Sent: February 4, 2026 12:33 AM
To: marjan banisaeed <mbanisaeed@hotmail.com<mailto:mbanisaeed@hotmail.com>>
Subject: Re: Corporate Law Firm

Hi Marjan

I've not looked at everything and this is not legal advice.

I believe there should be a third document titled the Franchise Disclosure Document or FDD. Do you have that?

Overall, I wonder if the problem is about the business or if it is, at the end day, driven by this particular individual. How would you describe the problem in your own words? If it is about the individual specifically, then it is essential to understand the legal relationship between her and the company. Is she one of the five people mentioned in the share purchase agreement, what is her name, is there a contract between her and the business?

Pls let me know!



Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

emails.snippet: Hi Matthew, 1. That makes sense I was thinking whoever needs to create the task can do it under the section but I agree user-wise that would create unnecessary work when they can just pick it from the
emails.body:
Hi Matthew,

1. That makes sense I was thinking whoever needs to create the task can do
it under the section but I agree user-wise that would create unnecessary
work when they can just pick it from the field. I can absolutely create
that automation!

2. Asana doesn't have an automation where the subtasks change based on the
section the task is moved into. We can do this:
- *Option 1:* We create one task template per section (each with its own
subtasks) and set a rule that when task is moved to Section X ‚Üí Convert
task to Template X. However, this overwrites the task with the template and
it will delete the comments, attachments, or custom progress.

- *Option 2:* We create one master task, have all possible subtasks once
(as we have now), group subtasks by color or prefix:

üü¶ - Onboarding
üü© - Opening
üü® - Maintenance

Sample subtask:

üü¶ DRAFT: Engagement Agreement
üü¶ CONFIRM: Engagement Agreement Stored in Clio

3. Sorry abt this, I thought whoever's handling Intake has their own board.
Let me know if this is something that we need in the future!

Kindly let me know your thoughts. Thanks!

emails.body:
Hi Matthew

Just quickly, just talked to the bank,,they said they have not received, or
see any transfer of funds into my account.Hopefully you can check on
your end, to see if there was an error made, concerning the transfer of the
funds.
    I'm sure it's all fine, and like you said it might take a day or two,
for the transfer to happen,,,but also it's good to double check..As soon as
the funds have been deposited into my account,I will let you know.

Thanks

Zeljko

emails.snippet: Hi LIno 1. Got it, I think we can delete the Fulfillment Stage column since we have them as Sections already deleting the fulfillment stage column seems fine. but, i believe there needs to be a field
emails.body:
Hi LIno

1. Got it, I think we can delete the Fulfillment Stage column since we have
them as Sections already

deleting the fulfillment stage column seems fine. but, i believe there
needs to be a field so that hte Fulfillment Stage can be set.  how about
some sort of automation whereby:


   1. human being sets the fulfillment stage field, card is moved to the
   relevant section.
   2. once card is moved to any particular section, the sub-task(s) for
   that section are populated?
      1. to be frank, im not sure that every single sub-task in the SOP
      needs to be an Asana sub-task. we can discuss this point.


2. I can rename it as that, just for consistency kindly name the other
Boards like Intake Tracker for consistency

so, i am open to that. what board are you talking about? is there a
specific "Intake" board at this stage?



*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor


This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.

emails.snippet: Hi Matthew, Have looked into the government funding and seems that anything that's available is for large companies and the loan amounts are aggressive. Do you have any ideas? Max Hill, CET Mascore
emails.body:
Hi Matthew,



Have looked into the government funding and seems that anything that‚Äôs
available is for large companies and the loan amounts are aggressive.



Do you have any ideas?



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389



*From:* Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
*Sent:* Monday, February 9, 2026 12:15 PM
*To:* Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
*Subject:* Re: New Project





Hey Max



When you have time, please let me know where things are at on your side and
any additional info I can informally review.



I would be confident in working on the government funding.





*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor



This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.







On Mon, Jan 12, 2026 at 12:11‚ÄØPM Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca> wrote:

I haven‚Äôt looked into the grant money that would be available for this but
will.



I would need some time to think about this.



Have been thinking of ways to create a product that is new and novel and
believe we have some decent idea.



You plan is great.



Give me some time to look into grant money. Please do not work on this
anymore until I get back to you.



I have enough info to push this forward for now.



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389



*From:* Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
*Sent:* Monday, January 12, 2026 12:06 PM
*To:* Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
*Subject:* Re: New Project



Hi Max



the patent lawyers who I know best are litigators but I do know some people
who do product development and will reach out.



I believe there may be government money available - have you looked into
that at all?



I see the next steps as:

   - *1. Legal Scoping*: counsel reviews the existing (U.S.) patent and
   scopes a design mandate focused on avoiding infringement under Canadian
   law. The scope and cost of this work will depend whether the goal is:


   - (a) to avoid infringing the existing patent (i.e., design-around), or
      - (b) to create something patentable by Mascore itself (i.e.,
      inventive and novel under the *Patent Act*).


   - *2 ‚Äì Technical Development*: The product designer works within
   specified parameters to generate technical outputs, i.e. designs, models,
   and prototypes to achieve (a) or (b)
   - *3 ‚Äì Legal Review*: counsel reviews the technical outputs and provides
   a follow-up opinion or informal assessment confirming whether the resulting
   design achieves (a) or (b)
   - *4 ‚Äì Filing & Prosecution (if pursuing a patent strategy)*: If the
   objective under Step 1 includes creating patentable subject matter, a
   separate workstream is initiated for preparation and prosecution of
   Mascore‚Äôs own patent application.

what do you think of the above?











*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor



This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.







On Fri, Jan 9, 2026 at 12:30‚ÄØPM Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca> wrote:

There is a US company that owns a patent on a unique deep foundation
product.



It is technically a helical pile, but it is modified and has a continuous
flight added to it that pull down concrete during installation making the
foundation much stronger. Attached is the brochure for reference.



Also attached is the Canadian and US patent.



My thoughts are:



   - The patent drawing is technically different from what they actually
   produce, although similar. The patent shows a helical shape plate with 2-3
   revolution where what they actually build is a single revolution helix
   plate.
   - We build a similar product already without a helix plate. See attached
   drawing.
   - Need to figure out a way to prove this isn‚Äôt ‚Äúnovel‚Äù
   - What type of modification can we make to it to make our own novelty?
   - An American company produces this and has plans to bring it to Canada.
   We‚Äôd like to stop this by competing with it.



I understand you earn a patent lawyer, but do you have any contacts?



Please let us know your thoughts.



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389



*From:* Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca>
*Sent:* Friday, January 9, 2026 11:11 AM
*To:* Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca>
*Subject:* Re: New Project



Hi Max



very interested. please send more info.



(i'm not a patent lawyer, as you know.)



happy new year





*Matthew AJ* *Levine*

Barrister & Solicitor



This message may contain confidential and / or privileged information and
is only to be used by the intended recipient. If you received this message
in error, please delete it and notify us. Thank you.







On Thu, Jan 8, 2026 at 9:12‚ÄØAM Max Hill <mhill@mascore.ca> wrote:

HI Matthew,



Hope you are well.



I have a new project I am working on that involved patent expertise.



There is an existing product in our market that we would like to start
offering that is patented.



We would like to build a similar product without infringing or having
ourselves covered in the event of a legal action.



Is this something you can help us with?



If so, I will provide further details.



Max Hill, C.E.T

Mascore Helical Piles

905-807-4389

Tulika - stream (Legal and Compliance)February 6th at 8:11 AM
Big news- Gemini Payments UK Ltd and Gemini Intergalactic UK Ltd exit the UK market
Gemini Payments UK, Ltd (GPUK) is authorised by the FCA to issue electronic money (e-money) and provide payment services.
Gemini Intergalactic UK, Ltd (GIUK) offers cryptoasset products. These activities are not regulated by the FCA, although the regulator oversee compliance in accordance with UK anti-money laundering regulations.
From 6 April 2026, Gemini is closing all customer accounts in the UK. On 5 February 2026, GPUK and GIUK confirmed they plan to exit the UK market.
Effective 6 April 2026, Gemini will close all customer accounts in the UK, in a phased wind-down exercise.
Until 4 March 2026, customers can continue using their accounts without disruption.
From 5 March 2026, all customer accounts will be placed in ‚Äòwithdrawal-only‚Äô mode.
Cryptoassets will come under FCA regulation in October 2027. The regulator want to develop a competitive and sustainable cryptoasset sector.

Tulika - stream (Legal and Compliance)February 6th at 8:22 AM
Practical insight and learnings from this case - key takeaways - https://support.gemini.com/hc/en-gb/articles/46255474469275-Gemini-closing-accounts-in-the-UK-EU-and-Australia-Everything-you-need-to-know

IN-PERSON OR LIVE WEBCAST

emails.snippet: Hi Vivien, Thank you for the helpful insights you've shared this morning, much appreciated. Apologies, Harry was unable to attend today as he is away. As mentioned on call I have looped in Matthew
emails.body:
Hi Vivien,

Thank you for the helpful insights you've shared this morning, much
appreciated.

Apologies, Harry was unable to attend today as he is away. As mentioned on

emails.body:
Webinar: February 12th, 11:00 AM Eastern

Ultimate SharePoint Status Board

Register and Save Your Spot

Your organization has critical processes that need to be monitored. The trouble is that you haven’t had a good way to display key status information from SharePoint. In our next webinar, we’ll show how Infowise Ultimate Forms provides the perfect solution to easily build a SharePoint Status Board with key measurements and indicators. Choose metrics that are most important to your organization. The setup process is easy to do with no coding required. We’ll cover:

  • Pick your own key metrics
  • Display measurements in color coded boxes
  • Add interactive filters
  • Automatically roll up key data
  • Data is refreshed automatically
  • Looks great on large TVs
  • Create additional custom boards for each team
  • Show open tickets, project health, sales numbers and more

Don’t miss this opportunity to learn how to set up your own powerful SharePoint Status Board. Download the complete solution template including lists, forms, views, automation, and the full Status Board page immediately after the presentation!

The recording and a free site template will be made available to all registrants.
Unsubscribe

emails.snippet: Energy transition, capital intensity, and the legal demand reshaping Tokyo Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè
emails.body:
View this post on the web at https://edgarems.substack.com/p/project-finance-as-a-core-growth

The M&A Baseline Before the Rise of Project Finance
For decades, mergers and acquisitions has been the primary practice area through which foreign-qualified lawyers built careers in Japan. Japan‚Äôs role as a major cross-border investment destination required international law firms to maintain strong M&A benches in Tokyo, often staffed by lawyers qualified in the US, UK, Australia, and other common-law jurisdictions.
While other practices periodically gained traction among foreign lawyers, M&A remained structurally dominant. It aligned with Japan‚Äôs inbound and outbound investment flows, required international documentation standards, and benefited from recurring transactional cycles.
That hierarchy, however, is no longer static.
Outside M&A, several practice areas have seen increased demand for foreign-qualified lawyers in Tokyo. Among them, energy and infrastructure project finance stands out for both scale and durability.
After two exceptionally busy years and with visible demand building into 2026, project finance has shifted from a complementary practice to a strategic priority. This is not only a hiring story, but a reflection of how capital deployment in Japan and the broader region is evolving.
How Large is Project Finance Hiring in Tokyo?
Before addressing the data, a caveat is necessary.
Tracking hiring trends in Tokyo‚Äôs energy and infrastructure legal market is inherently imperfect. Any dataset limited to lawyers currently in private practice will undercount prior cycles, as senior lawyers may have moved in-house, relocated, or exited the market altogether. Historical comparisons should therefore be read directionally rather than as precise headcount measurements.
With that limitation in mind, a clear pattern still emerges.
Based on a review of foreign-qualified lawyers currently practicing energy and infrastructure project finance within Tokyo-based private practice teams, hiring has accelerated materially over the last four years, with a pronounced concentration in 2024 and 2025.
Between 2016 and 2020, annual joins were consistently in the low single digits. These hires largely reflected replacement hiring or isolated strategic additions. From 2021 onward, volumes increased meaningfully, rising to six to nine joins per year through 2022 and 2023.
In 2024, foreign-qualified project finance hiring rose again, with fourteen recored joins. A further thirteen joins have already been identified in 2025. (Refer to Graph 1)
Notably, a large share of the 2024 cohort joined in the second half of the year. This suggests firms were not merely reacting to completed transactions, but hiring in anticipation of increased activity.
That interpretation reinforced by early-2026 dynamics. Despite the year only just beginning, multiple international law firms in Tokyo are actively recruiting foreign-qualified project finance lawyers across associate, counsel, and partner levels.
What Changed Over the Past Decade?
From 2016 to 2025, energy and infrastructure moved from a steady, long-cycle sector into a capital-heavy transition cycle. The clearest quantitative signal is the scale and speed of energy investment growth since 2020. The IEA estimates global energy investment is set to exceed USD 3 trillion in 2024, with USD 2 trillion directed to clean energy technologies and infrastructure, including renewables, grids, and storage. By 2025, BloombergNEF estimates global energy transition investment alone reached USD 2.3 trillion, up 8% YoY, with large allocations to electrified transport, renewables, and grids. In other words, the market experienced not only more projects, but more projects that were finance-intensive, cross-border, and contract-heavy, which is exactly the profile that increases demand for sophisticated project finance legal support.
Regionally, Asia sits ant the center of that pipeline because the underlying infrastructure requirement remains massive and multi-decade. The Asian Development Bank estimated developing Asia would need USD 26 trillion of infrastructure investment from 2016 to 2030, or roughly USD 1.7 trillion per year, to maintain growth momentum and address infrastructure gaps. Japan links directly into that regional cycle as a sponsor and financing hub, while also building its domestic transition pipeline.
METI has framed Green Transformation as a ten-year investment agenda, stating more than JPY 150 trillion of public-private investment is required over the next decade, with JPY 20 trillion of GC Economy Transition Bonds to support it. On the project side, offshore wind moved from policy to awarded pipeline. NEDO materials describer Round 1 auctions finalized in 2021 with 1.7 GQ awarded, and Japan‚Äôs Strategic Energy Plan sets ambitions to form 10GW of projects by 2030 and 30 to 45 GW by 2040.
Japan also tightened its long-term decarbonization trajectory in its UNFCC submission, targeting 60 % emissions reduction by FY2035 and 73% by FY2040 from FY2013 levels. Together, these shifts help explain why Tokyo-based firms expanded benches of foreign-qualified project finance lawyers: more capital, more cross-border structures, and more projects where international financing standards and documentation norms are decisive.
Rare Earth Materials and Project Finance Demand
Critical minerals, including REMs, have become a further driver of project finance demand since 2020, accelerating sharply over the past year as economies outside China seek supply chain resilience.
As energy transition technologies scale, mining, processing, and refining projects are increasingly financed on standalone or structured basis rather than through corporate balance sheets. Demand for critical minerals used in clean energy technologies is expected to multiply by 2030.
For Japan-based sponsors and lenders, these projects are often overseas and involve long-term offtake arrangements, political risk mitigation, export credit agency support, and development finance participation. Structurally, they resemble classic project finance transactions rather than conventional M&A.
As a result, international project finance documentation and market-standard structures are becoming more prevalent, reinforcing demand for foreign-qualified lawyers within Tokyo-based private practice teams.
What This Means for 2026 and Beyond
Early 2026 signals point to continued expansion rather than normalization.
As of February, multiple international law firms in Tokyo are actively seeking to add foreign-qualified E&I lawyers. Importantly, these searches are not driven by attrition. They are capacity-driven.
Across the market, firms cite similar factors. Deal pipelines are growing. Lead times for project finance mandates are lengthening. Energy transition, infrastructure, LNG transition assets, and critical minerals work increasingly overlap.
This matters because project finance hiring typically precedes deal execution. Firms build capacity ahead of bid stages, lender panel appointments, and financial close cycles. The current hiring activity therefore reflects expectations of sustained workload through 2026 and beyond, not just recent deal flow.
Taken together, these dynamics suggest that project finance is no longer a niche or counter-cyclical practice within Tokyo‚Äôs foreign-qualified legal market. It is becoming a core strategic capability, increasingly comparable to M&A in headcount importance and long-term relevance.
If the previous decade was defined by cross-border corporate transactions, the next may be defined by cross-border capital deployment into assets. For foreign-qualified lawyers in Tokyo, project finance is no longer an alternative track It is rapidly becoming one of the main ones.
Sources
International Energy Agency (IEA), World Energy Investment 2024
https://www.iea.org/reports/world-energy-investment-2024/overview-and-key-findings [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/e09e5301-5672-448e-8dbf-7d8619c16f5e?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]
BloombergNEF, Energy Transition Investment Trends 2025
https://about.bnef.com/insights/clean-energy/bloombergnef-finds-global-energy-transition-investment-reached-record-2-3-trillion-in-2025-up-8-from-2024/ [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/03811a80-24a4-4095-a55f-5a7e5df9f92d?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]
Asian Development Bank (ADB), Asia Infrastructure Needs: Meeting the Challenge
https://www.adb.org/publications/asia-infrastructure-needs [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/de1e27d5-1aa8-4581-b470-7f4192b1a851?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]
Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Japan, Green Transformation (GX) Policy and Transition Finance
https://www.meti.go.jp/english/policy/energy_environment/transition_finance/index.html [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/2b9e07d4-1905-4557-97f6-5ff78da6233a?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]
METI / Agency for Natural Resources and Energy (ANRE), Strategic Energy Plan
https://www.enecho.meti.go.jp/category/others/basic_plan/ [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/7d06e556-f80e-4c30-a6b8-3278eec13085?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]

https://www.nedo.go.jp/content/100949197.pdf [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/363c4f49-4f4c-4423-9041-472b9a1ba727?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]
ESGian, Results of Japan‚Äôs Second Offshore Wind Round
https://esgian.com/2023/12/13/results-of-second-offshore-wind-round-in-japan-announced/ [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/3bfba165-72c3-4408-949f-8a3d75d17b24?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]

https://www.whitecase.com/insight-alert/japan-offshore-wind-update-round-3-results [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/78e1233e-19f3-4b6c-8cb7-347363436534?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]
UNFCCC, Japan‚Äôs 2035‚Äì2040 Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC)
https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/2025-02/Japans%202035-2040%20NDC.pdf [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/de9a876b-4dfb-482a-95d1-2c1a42701ba5?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]

https://www.iea.org/reports/the-role-of-critical-minerals-in-clean-energy-transitions [ https://link.sbstck.com/redirect/7bcbabc4-9b53-492c-892b-ffd5b417992e?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]

Hi Matthew,

I know Yash spoke with you and the plan was to reconnect mid February. At this point, several pieces remain up in the air‚Äîparticularly following our last communication with the bank, where there is still no clear direction on the status of the equipment.

Unfortunately, this ongoing uncertainty has left us in a more difficult financial position. While we are very grateful for the flexibility provided through the payment plan, we are not currently in a position to make the final installment owed. Based on the invoices we‚Äôve received, I do believe we are otherwise up to date on payments to date.

Given the circumstances, we would like to respectfully request to cease our retainer at this time and, if possible, not proceed with the final payment. This is not a reflection of your efforts, but rather our current financial constraints and the lack of forward momentum we are able to act on.

Should our situation change and we find ourselves in a position to move forward meaningfully, would it be acceptable for us to reach out to you again at that time to potentially resume services?

Thank you again for your time and support, and we appreciate your understanding.

Warm regards,

Hello Janet

Nice to meet you. As you know, my firm acts for Kishmish Inc. (the ‚ÄúFranchisee‚Äù) and Yash Raj and Jyotika Luthra (the ‚ÄúFranchisee Principals‚Äù).



After sustained operating losses and escalating costs, Kishmish has undertaken a financial and strategic review of its business viability. The review confirmed that continued operation under the existing structure is no longer feasible. My clients wish to ensure that any transition occurs in an orderly and cooperative manner that protects the brand, the premises, and all parties‚Äô interests.



Accordingly, and without prejudice to any of Kishmish‚Äôs legal or statutory rights, we are instructed to open a dialogue with you to structure a mutual termination and surrender process on the following framework:

  1.  Orderly Transition ‚Äì Kishmish will coordinate a prompt wind-down of operations, return of keys, turnover of the premises and equipment in good order, and transfer of employees on a schedule acceptable to Nani‚Äôs.
  2.  Orderly Surrender ‚Äì Upon delivery of vacant possession, Nani‚Äôs will accept surrender of the sublease and franchise location in satisfaction of Kishmish‚Äôs remaining obligations.
  3.  Mutual Release ‚Äì The parties will execute a mutual release confirming that no further claims will be made by either party, other than those that may be expressly provided in the release and waiver documentation.
  4.  Brand Protection and Confidentiality ‚Äì Kishmish will return all confidential materials and intellectual-property assets in accordance with the franchise agreement. It will enter into a confidentiality agreement on mutually acceptable terms.

Kishmish continues to operate in good faith pending these discussions and is prepared to cooperate fully in a controlled handover that minimizes disruption.

Please confirm a convenient time to discuss. We would appreciate receiving your acknowledgement so that we can promptly coordinate next steps.

All of our client‚Äôs statutory, contractual, and equitable rights are expressly reserved.

Kind regards

Matthew

Subject: Nani's - Liberty Village franchise unit and sub-lease




Hello Janet

Nice to meet you. As you know, my firm acts for Kishmish Inc. (the ‚ÄúFranchisee‚Äù) and Yash Raj and Jyotika Luthra (the ‚ÄúFranchisee Principals‚Äù).



After sustained operating losses and escalating costs, Kishmish has undertaken a financial and strategic review of its business viability. The review confirmed that continued operation under the existing structure is no longer feasible. My clients wish to ensure that any transition occurs in an orderly and cooperative manner that protects the brand, the premises, and all parties‚Äô interests.



Accordingly, and without prejudice to any of Kishmish‚Äôs legal or statutory rights, we are instructed to open a dialogue with you to structure a mutual termination and surrender process on the following framework:

  1.  Orderly Transition ‚Äì Kishmish will coordinate a prompt wind-down of operations, return of keys, turnover of the premises and equipment in good order, and transfer of employees on a schedule acceptable to Nani‚Äôs.
  2.  Orderly Surrender ‚Äì Upon delivery of vacant possession, Nani‚Äôs will accept surrender of the sublease and franchise location in satisfaction of Kishmish‚Äôs remaining obligations.
  3.  Mutual Release ‚Äì The parties will execute a mutual release confirming that no further claims will be made by either party, other than those that may be expressly provided in the release and waiver documentation.
  4.  Brand Protection and Confidentiality ‚Äì Kishmish will return all confidential materials and intellectual-property assets in accordance with the franchise agreement. It will enter into a confidentiality agreement on mutually acceptable terms.

Kishmish continues to operate in good faith pending these discussions and is prepared to cooperate fully in a controlled handover that minimizes disruption.

Please confirm a convenient time to discuss. We would appreciate receiving your acknowledgement so that we can promptly coordinate next steps.

All of our client‚Äôs statutory, contractual, and equitable rights are expressly reserved.

Kind regards

Matthew

Subject: Nani's - Liberty Village franchise unit and sub-lease




Hello Janet

Nice to meet you. As you know, my firm acts for Kishmish Inc. (the ‚ÄúFranchisee‚Äù) and Yash Raj and Jyotika Luthra (the ‚ÄúFranchisee Principals‚Äù).



After sustained operating losses and escalating costs, Kishmish has undertaken a financial and strategic review of its business viability. The review confirmed that continued operation under the existing structure is no longer feasible. My clients wish to ensure that any transition occurs in an orderly and cooperative manner that protects the brand, the premises, and all parties‚Äô interests.



Accordingly, and without prejudice to any of Kishmish‚Äôs legal or statutory rights, we are instructed to open a dialogue with you to structure a mutual termination and surrender process on the following framework:

  1.  Orderly Transition ‚Äì Kishmish will coordinate a prompt wind-down of operations, return of keys, turnover of the premises and equipment in good order, and transfer of employees on a schedule acceptable to Nani‚Äôs.
  2.  Orderly Surrender ‚Äì Upon delivery of vacant possession, Nani‚Äôs will accept surrender of the sublease and franchise location in satisfaction of Kishmish‚Äôs remaining obligations.
  3.  Mutual Release ‚Äì The parties will execute a mutual release confirming that no further claims will be made by either party, other than those that may be expressly provided in the release and waiver documentation.
  4.  Brand Protection and Confidentiality ‚Äì Kishmish will return all confidential materials and intellectual-property assets in accordance with the franchise agreement. It will enter into a confidentiality agreement on mutually acceptable terms.

Kishmish continues to operate in good faith pending these discussions and is prepared to cooperate fully in a controlled handover that minimizes disruption.

Please confirm a convenient time to discuss. We would appreciate receiving your acknowledgement so that we can promptly coordinate next steps.

All of our client‚Äôs statutory, contractual, and equitable rights are expressly reserved.

Kind regards

Matthew











Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

Hi Matthew,

I hope you‚Äôre doing well. I wanted to connect regarding where things currently stand.

I know Yash spoke with you and the plan was to reconnect mid February. At this point, several pieces remain up in the air‚Äîparticularly following our last communication with the bank, where there is still no clear direction on the status of the equipment.

Unfortunately, this ongoing uncertainty has left us in a more difficult financial position. While we are very grateful for the flexibility provided through the payment plan, we are not currently in a position to make the final installment owed. Based on the invoices we‚Äôve received, I do believe we are otherwise up to date on payments to date.

Given the circumstances, we would like to respectfully request to cease our retainer at this time and, if possible, not proceed with the final payment. This is not a reflection of your efforts, but rather our current financial constraints and the lack of forward momentum we are able to act on.

Should our situation change and we find ourselves in a position to move forward meaningfully, would it be acceptable for us to reach out to you again at that time to potentially resume services?

Thank you again for your time and support, and we appreciate your understanding.

From: Matthew Levine <matthew@levinelegal.ca<mailto:matthew@levinelegal.ca>>
Sent: November 5, 2025 2:20 PM
To: Janet Erskine <janet.erskine@ship-law-adr.ca<mailto:janet.erskine@ship-law-adr.ca>>
Cc: Levine Law Office <office@levinelegal.ca<mailto:office@levinelegal.ca>>
Subject: Nani's - Liberty Village franchise unit and sub-lease




Hello Janet

Nice to meet you. As you know, my firm acts for Kishmish Inc. (the ‚ÄúFranchisee‚Äù) and Yash Raj and Jyotika Luthra (the ‚ÄúFranchisee Principals‚Äù).



After sustained operating losses and escalating costs, Kishmish has undertaken a financial and strategic review of its business viability. The review confirmed that continued operation under the existing structure is no longer feasible. My clients wish to ensure that any transition occurs in an orderly and cooperative manner that protects the brand, the premises, and all parties‚Äô interests.



Accordingly, and without prejudice to any of Kishmish‚Äôs legal or statutory rights, we are instructed to open a dialogue with you to structure a mutual termination and surrender process on the following framework:

  1.  Orderly Transition ‚Äì Kishmish will coordinate a prompt wind-down of operations, return of keys, turnover of the premises and equipment in good order, and transfer of employees on a schedule acceptable to Nani‚Äôs.
  2.  Orderly Surrender ‚Äì Upon delivery of vacant possession, Nani‚Äôs will accept surrender of the sublease and franchise location in satisfaction of Kishmish‚Äôs remaining obligations.
  3.  Mutual Release ‚Äì The parties will execute a mutual release confirming that no further claims will be made by either party, other than those that may be expressly provided in the release and waiver documentation.
  4.  Brand Protection and Confidentiality ‚Äì Kishmish will return all confidential materials and intellectual-property assets in accordance with the franchise agreement. It will enter into a confidentiality agreement on mutually acceptable terms.

Kishmish continues to operate in good faith pending these discussions and is prepared to cooperate fully in a controlled handover that minimizes disruption.

Please confirm a convenient time to discuss. We would appreciate receiving your acknowledgement so that we can promptly coordinate next steps.

All of our client‚Äôs statutory, contractual, and equitable rights are expressly reserved.

Kind regards

Matthew











Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor



1235 Bay Street, Suite 700, TORONTO, M5R 3K4

T: +1 (647) 598-2598

> Hello Janet
>
> Nice to meet you. As you know, my firm acts for Kishmish Inc. (the
> ‚ÄúFranchisee‚Äù) and Yash Raj and Jyotika Luthra (the ‚ÄúFranchisee
> Principals‚Äù).
>
>
>
> After sustained operating losses and escalating costs, Kishmish has
> undertaken a financial and strategic review of its business viability. The
> review confirmed that continued operation under the existing structure is
> no longer feasible. My clients wish to ensure that any transition occurs in
> an orderly and cooperative manner that protects the brand, the premises,
> and all parties‚Äô interests.
>
>
>
> Accordingly, and without prejudice to any of Kishmish‚Äôs legal or statutory
> rights, we are instructed to open a dialogue with you to structure a mutual
> termination and surrender process on the following framework:
>
>    1. Orderly Transition ‚Äì Kishmish will coordinate a prompt wind-down of
>    operations, return of keys, turnover of the premises and equipment in good
>    order, and transfer of employees on a schedule acceptable to Nani‚Äôs.
>    2. Orderly Surrender ‚Äì Upon delivery of vacant possession, Nani‚Äôs will
>    accept surrender of the sublease and franchise location in satisfaction of
>    Kishmish‚Äôs remaining obligations.
>    3. Mutual Release ‚Äì The parties will execute a mutual release
>    confirming that no further claims will be made by either party, other than
>    those that may be expressly provided in the release and waiver
>    documentation.
>    4. Brand Protection and Confidentiality ‚Äì Kishmish will return all
>    confidential materials and intellectual-property assets in accordance with
>    the franchise agreement. It will enter into a confidentiality agreement on
>    mutually acceptable terms.
>
> Kishmish continues to operate in good faith pending these discussions and
> is prepared to cooperate fully in a controlled handover that minimizes
> disruption.
>
> Please confirm a convenient time to discuss. We would appreciate receiving
> your acknowledgement so that we can promptly coordinate next steps.
>
> All of our client‚Äôs statutory, contractual, and equitable rights are
> expressly reserved.
>
>
> Kind regards

üíñ It was truly special spending 4 days together and watching this community show up with such heart, energy and openness. We're so grateful you were part of it.

Comment se d√©sinscrire ou g√©rer vos pr√©f√©rences. Si nos e-mails ne vous semblent plus pertinents, il n‚Äôy a aucune rancune. Posizione su sicurezza e privacy. Non chiediamo mai dettagli di pagamento o informazioni sensibili via email. Gli ordini sono gestiti tramite processi sicuri. Qualora fosse necessario aggiornare i dettagli di consegna, qualcuno del nostro team di Robbins Research International, Inc potrebbe contattarti. Tieni presente che non richiediamo informazioni di pagamento personali via email. La trasparenza √® la nostra priorit√† e siamo lieti di rispondere a qualsiasi domanda tu possa avere. Anche se non possiamo garantire che ogni suggerimento venga implementato, ci prenderemo il tempo necessario per esaminare attentamente e considerare il tuo contributo. Accessibilit√† e comunicazione. Le nostre comunicazioni sono progettate per essere il pi√π inclusive possibile, ma sappiamo che c‚Äô√® sempre margine di miglioramento. Rispettiamo tutte le leggi e i regolamenti applicabili in materia di comunicazioni via email. La tua fiducia √® importante e lavoriamo con impegno per garantire che ogni email che ricevi soddisfi tali requisiti. Se hai bisogno di ulteriori chiarimenti sulle nostre politiche di conformit√† o sugli obblighi legali, non esitare a chiedere. Trasparenza e responsabilit√† sono centrali nella nostra strategia di comunicazione e saremo lieti di fornire ulteriori dettagli se necessario. Informazioni di contatto. Ci impegniamo a garantire che tutti i canali di comunicazione siano aperti e facilmente accessibili. Che si tratti di una domanda, di un commento o di una segnalazione, il nostro team √® pronto ad assisterti. Subject: Re: SPA



Hi Alon



My specific edits are attached. Just to be clear: Yellowbricks will be sold by the numbered company, not me personally; the full name of Yellowbricks is Yellowbricks Capital Incorporated. FINTRAC unfortunately created one document with an 'o' in Capitol but that is purely their administrative typo.



Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.



In terms of the KYC, on behalf of 17513721 Canada Inc. and Yellowbricks, please provide the following KYC information for the Purchaser (and any ultimate beneficial owners, if different):

  *   Full legal name of the Purchaser (and any parent or holding entity)
  *   Jurisdiction of incorporation / formation
  *   Registered address and principal place of business
  *   Names of directors and officers
  *   Ultimate beneficial owners (natural persons), including ownership percentages
  *   Government-issued identification for each UBO (passport or equivalent)
  *   Confirmation of source of funds for the purchase
  *   Any existing regulatory status, licenses, or registrations (if applicable)

If the Purchaser is acting through an SPV or nominee structure, please include the full ownership and control chain.

Let me know if you have any questions.

Kind regards





Matthew AJ Levine

Barrister & Solicitor

Edit or close your job posting

Hi Matthew,

This email confirms that your job post for GoHighLevel implementer: https://www.upwork.com/jobs/~022008660010031685968?utm_medium=email&utm_source=mailgun&utm_campaign=reminders%2Fopening_expires_soon_to_buyer&email_uid=2020179762945482752&frkscc=xwBZgm58EfxW will expire in 5 days due to inactivity.

If you are still hiring, edit the post to automatically extend the expiration date. To edit your job, click the Jobs tab, locate the job in your Open Jobs, and then click Edit Posting in the Actions menu. 

By default, when a job is posted on the platform, it is open for 30 days. If no freelancer is selected the job will expire. In order to extend the job posting, you must edit it. Editing the job post will extend the posting period for an additional 30 days. Any small change will result in the post being extended.

Edit Job Post: https://www.upwork.com/c/5688309/jobs/~022008660010031685968/edit?frkscc=Ixv77NckVkqt
