emails.snippet: What does ‚Äúvalue‚Äù mean to operations teams once AI becomes ubiquitous? How do operational realities break most AI promises? Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè Õè
emails.body:
View this post on the web at https://cashandcarried.substack.com/p/from-client-to-customer-how-a-private

Cash and Carried‚Äôs first interview of the year, and its first long form piece ever - with Omar Hassan [ https://substack.com/redirect/dbaad5cc-ca33-458a-98df-eda501cdaab4?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ], CFO & COO of Cloverlay [ https://substack.com/redirect/59182da8-2167-4afd-8756-f490ab124e78?j=eyJ1IjoiNXZmeXByIn0.McNV8o2DlmmyS6C076LNFFfWD2xVnU1eV3nZgmD2JTU ]. I hope you enjoy reading it as much as Omar and I enjoyed the conversation.
There have been obvious and perceptible changes in the world of investment management with the arrival of AI. Even as some of them are clearly visible (and further, clearly transformative) they hardly receive warranted attention.
Among them is a new cadre of empowered buyers, who have always been ever-present in the decision-making calculus of private fund managers: CFOs and COOs.
To be blunt, while AI has transformed the ability to do work, it has made the administration associated with its implementation and adoption much more difficult. 
That is, technology never comes with a playbook on how it should be used, only the fact that it must be used. Its most confident originators are excellent in touting this inevitability, and the torrent of compulsion to use it creates much of the confusion we see in operating teams today.
Further, and as such, the absolute emergence of AI and the overwhelming flood of AI solutions for the endless array of manual human activity has sharpened the need for pivotal decision-making from these buyers.
Somehow‚Äîperhaps unknowingly and unwillingly‚Äîthey were given the enormous task of evaluating the quality of that flood, ensuring an appropriate analysis and implementation, and further expected to do so confidently and efficiently, alongside and in addition to their traditional work.
These professionals are astute observers to the blunderbuss sanguinity of this era‚Äôs greatest technological innovation. At once they are also keenly aware of the thing left to utter abandon by AI‚Äôs greatest champions, the human touch, now a common retroactive marketing gambit many AI companies employ as they run up against the stormy realities of implementation and adoption.
Could there be a more obvious admission than this oblique promotional pivot that technology was neither the complete answer nor the primary one to the most pressing challenges in high finance?
On these matters, I recently had the honored pleasure of speaking to one of the industry‚Äôs sharpest voices: Omar Hassan, CFO and COO of the esoteric, captivating investment manager, Cloverlay.
As the first fever of excitement around AI began to cool, we found ourselves drawn toward weightier questions. Less about what the technology could do, and more about what kind of future it was arranging for us, one in which its presence would be as unavoidable as it was ordinary.
The Esoteric Play
Cloverlay positions its investment thesis on the premise of ‚Äúadjacent‚Äù private markets. Investment opportunities that have existed outside the conventional preserve of private equity and private credit.
His views on technology and as a buyer standing at the gates of the AI-induced flood are anything but conventional.
‚ÄúI take a nontraditional view on a lot of these topics. What [tech] people traditionally want to do is ask, ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs your problem?‚Äô Or ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs causing you stress?‚Äô‚Äù
He paused before answering his own question.
For me, it always comes back to something else: ‚ÄúWhy should I care?‚Äù
Time as Investment
From a COO‚Äôs vantage point, time is the greatest scarcity. It presses in from every side, allowing no room for abstractions, no indulgence in ideas that demand faith before proof. Each new system arrives already under suspicion, compelled to justify itself immediately or be dismissed as yet another burden disguised as some sort of salvation.
‚ÄúIt has to be a no-brainer,‚Äù Omar said. ‚ÄúVery little implementation.‚Äù
This is where the language of sales begins to feel almost distasteful. Its grand promises of transformation ring loudly, and yet collapse under the inward severity of operational life, where nothing is forgiven just because it sounds convincing.
‚ÄúI get really annoyed when they say, ‚Äòthis will save you ninety percent of your time,‚Äô‚Äù Omar continued. ‚ÄúWhen push comes to shove, you‚Äôre still on calls telling people what they need to do.‚Äù
For operations teams in large organizations, this can take dozens of hours a month.
The time drag sharpens because of a lack of disciplinary context. In other words, does the person across the table understand how things work?
‚ÄúDo you know my business?‚Äù he stated.
Account executives and the garden variety salesforce have little to offer in this manner of things.
But for many account managers, securing a demo feels like progress. For the operator, it is already an investment.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre asking why I should care,‚Äù Omar said, ‚Äúyou better not waste my time. There‚Äôs an element of: my thinking, my ideas, time, and data are not free. Because I know that‚Äôs the value they‚Äôll get out of it.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt sounds less about product, and more about messaging and marketing,‚Äù I responded, stating the plainly obvious (as I tend to do).
Omar agreed. But there was an attendant point about how tech companies position their value, and he was livid about the lack of transparency.
‚ÄúThese tech companies will say they will let the data work for you. They are obviously leaving out the how, and they want to show you that in the demo.‚Äù
Is there a saving grace for precious operational daylight?
‚ÄúI‚Äôm a big believer in the shorts. The quick demo video shorts not just a video that re explains the problem that is being tried to solve. Time is very valuable.‚Äù
Killing a Tool
If one is able to get past the obstacle of time, to the point of a pilot or implementation, new hazards emerge. Still, certain principles persist.
‚ÄúI have to feel like it is way easier.‚Äù
No tradeoffs.
Omar gave the example of Concur, the expense reporting tool. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not‚Ä¶cool...but it works for the whole manager.‚Äù
And migrating to something new, even if it is technically better, has sunk costs that are generally hard to overcome. ‚ÄúIf we go to another expense software, there are noticeable tradeoffs even if the product is better.‚Äù
The white-glove service that fund managers are typically used to figures centrally into the arithmetic: ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt want to engage unless you are holistically solving a particular pain or you tell me exactly how I‚Äôm doing it when we are talking.‚Äù
This is something of an unspoken (and at worst, unknown) hurdle swashbuckling tech companies servicing fund managers struggle to understand. A private equity fund is used to calling up professional service providers that can produce anything‚Äîa CIM, LPA, market deck, etc.‚Äîto the exact specifications of the VP or managing director.
That‚Äôs why lawyers and bankers can charge so much, and their clients are willing to pay for it (there are other considerations, but this one is a mainstay!).
A fund manager is used to be treated like a client, not a customer. What‚Äôs more, Omar mentioned, is that much of the salesforce have probably never worked at a fund manager before.
Anecdotally, I recently recall having a conversation with a fintech that provides retail access to the private markets. The account executive didn‚Äôt know what a 3(c)(7) fund was. And if you are a broker dealer (which these types of businesses are), you are in the business of selling interests in a third-party fund. So to not know the type of fund, which has implications for the kind of people you sell too, can be reflective of the company‚Äôs foundational basis.
This is perhaps to harsh an assessment of the conventional venture-backed tech company.
To meet the expectations of the venture world‚Äôs increasingly aggressive demands for scale, the tech companies aren‚Äôt entirely to blame either. As a white-glove service provider, Kirkland & Ellis generated over $7 billion in revenue last year as the nation‚Äôs top grossing law firm.
Harvey, Silicon Valley‚Äôs legal AI darling, is already worth $8 billion in its 3-and-a-half-year existence.
The high pressure to grow spills into pushy behavior. As Omar put it, ‚ÄúThere are elements of overselling‚Äù that are sources of significant consternation.
What‚Äôs worse is the stuff left out, only to be revealed at painfully inconvenient moments. Somewhat regretfully, Omar recalled a compliance system that had a feature he really liked. ‚ÄúWhat drove me crazy was that during the implementation phase the team left out as to whether it was going to work.‚Äù
And this type of incident isn‚Äôt isolated. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of ‚Äòtell us what we want to hear, but sell us what they want to sell‚Äô.‚Äù While it is useful to have a meeting of the minds, the typical posture of a tech salesforce is that it can get challenging to close when it feels, as Omar put it, ‚Äúlike they are messing with you.‚Äù
Evaluating Failures
There is a clear desire among the operations team at fund managers to be cognizant of a trustworthy salesperson. This isn‚Äôt a unique mindset, and the forces driving it are equally ubiquitous.
Part of that awareness comes in the form of founder experience. Cloverlay was an early adopter of a software for which one of the founders was an investment professional. ‚ÄúThey knew what we needed.‚Äù
The technical know-how trickles down through company culture, and is the basis of an informed salesforce.
The one thing which Omar was clear any good account executive should avoid: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask the magic wand question.‚Äù An expert-led tech company wouldn‚Äôt ever need to go down this cliched script.
Assuming a tech company can get past the initial stage of implementation, there are nonetheless evident signs that the rollout lacked the teeth to be truly useful.
But let‚Äôs say it is useful, and the customer is happy.
Can that level of satisfaction endure beyond the narrow time horizon of a venture capitalist outlook? Even as this class of investor is struggling to itself return capital to its limited partner base‚Äîit can easily take 12-14 years after the initial ‚Äúclose‚Äù of the fund, which is when the first batch of investors is formally admitted‚Äîthe ideal assumption for a fund manager, or any customer for that matter, is that as prices increase, so should the quality of service.
The reality is murkier, and even when things are clear, they aren‚Äôt pretty.
For managers that have illiquid strategies like Cloverlay, this plays out in the medium to long term. ‚ÄúThere has to be a better way where you are taking care of your legacy clients‚Äù that are captive to the software.
Account success teams, as they are usually referred to in traditional SaaS, are tasked with maintaining continued relations with existing customers and driving retention. This can also involve upselling new products from time to time.
When these teams fall short, it comes out in the form of tiered experiences for the customer base. It‚Äôs not that someone paying less should receive the same treatment as someone paying 10x more. But that the sense of care given shouldn‚Äôt be any different.
Optimists might say customers are a genuine part of a software‚Äôs cohesive ecosystem. Omar‚Äôs posture is skeptical: ‚ÄúThey [legacy providers] know that for us to think of an integration project [namely, data migration] with someone else, it‚Äôll take months.‚Äù
Perhaps what legacy providers struggle with most is the visible practice of care: the ongoing demonstration that a customer‚Äôs success remains an active concern.
Reliance on the product only sharpens the tension. When dependency turns into a feeling of entrapment, it is usually the clearest signal that the relationship itself has atrophied. Not through malice, but through neglect, as alternatives recede beyond reach.
Cynics would argue this dynamic persists today. Technological evolution races ahead, while the more modest work of sustaining trust (attention, responsiveness, adaptation) lags behind, treated as ancillary rather than foundational to the business itself.
Innovation advances easily but sustaining care does not. The latter is always the first to be abandoned.
Intervention and Letting Things Fail
Stickiness and long-term adoption work hand in hand. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost like taking a pulse.‚Äù When adoption becomes a problem, the falloff isn‚Äôt as dramatic.
At that stage, intervention is less about retraining and more about triage. Sometimes the answer is substitution: an existing function inside the AWS or Microsoft stack can replicate 80% of the value at a fraction of the cost. Sometimes the question is more blunt. ‚ÄúAre we just wasting money?‚Äù Omar said stridently.
Yet even that discipline has its exceptions. Artificial intelligence, for now, lives outside the normal rules of enterprise hygiene.
‚ÄúWe have Copilot, Claude, GPT,‚Äù Omar notes. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre using all of them, for different things.‚Äù
Rather than forcing standardization, firms are tolerating fragmentation. These tools are still too foundational, too fast-moving, to prematurely optimize. The goal is exposure, and efficiency comes in at a close second. Teams are encouraged to experiment broadly, to understand not just what the models can do, but how they want to be used.
This has already begun to reorder older workflows. PowerPoint, once an industry sweetheart, is falling out of fashion.
Much of the public conversation around AI focuses on replacement. In the world of fund manager operations, the emphasis is different.
‚ÄúFor the most nuanced operators,‚Äù Omar notes, ‚ÄúAI doesn‚Äôt replace workflows. It forces you to change them.‚Äù
The opportunity is not in swapping out one tool for another, but in rethinking how information enters the system in the first place. That requires abandoning linear processes in favor of modular ones, assembling constellations of narrowly focused tools, rather than betting on a single, end-to-end platform.
This posture acts as a sort of counter-narrative to the one that prevails among AI romantics. Point solutions are seen as weaker business propositions by both founders and venture capitalists. In other words, the ideal product should be able to analyze, then incorporate, and then solve an entire business process.
To support this, Omar points to the emerging ecosystem of model context protocols and AI agents. These are systems that can be combined, trained, and orchestrated rather than deployed wholesale. The aspiration is not just automation, but continuity.
But an end-to-end product does have its virtues. Omar, if not forthrightly, admitted as much.
‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm in my car in the morning,‚Äù he says, ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt be asking for only a summary of my calendar. That‚Äôs old school. Very 2025.‚Äù
The more ambitious vision is ambient capture. A phone call ends and the substance of the conversation flows directly into the calendar, the task list, and the CRM, without manual translation.
Email and chat tools like Superhuman hint at this future, but they are still surface-level. The deeper challenge is architectural: designing systems that assume intelligence at the core, not bolted on at the edges.
Why Enterprise Tech Still Falls Short
As we wrapped up our conversation, I asked Omar about the single biggest reason enterprise technology fails inside fund managers.
Initially, he resisted the premise. The familiar culprits (bad data, weak change management, misaligned incentives) are not really competitors. They are work cumulatively.
Still, one tends to lead.
‚ÄúWeak data is number one,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBecause getting clean data into a system, without AI and without strong workflows, is work people don‚Äôt want to do.‚Äù
Why would an investment professional, whose edge depends on personal heuristics and idiosyncratic views, willingly conform to a standardized schema?
This is why end-to-end enterprise solutions struggle. They promise coherence but demand significant behavioral change at the point of highest resistance. The more comprehensive the system, the more it collides with how people actually think and work.
The alternative, still aspirational but increasingly plausible, is a strong central data infrastructure paired with highly specialized tools at the edges. A stable core with flexible peripherals. Enough structure to ensure integrity, enough freedom to preserve conviction.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the holy grail,‚Äù Hassan says. ‚ÄúStrong data underneath, niche tools on top.‚Äù
What fails, again and again, are platforms that try to do everything. In doing so, they ask users to give up the very practices that made them effective in the first place.

Unsubscribe https://substack.com/redirect/2/eyJlIjoiaHR0cHM6Ly9jYXNoYW5kY2FycmllZC5zdWJzdGFjay5jb20vYWN0aW9uL2Rpc2FibGVfZW1haWw_.yCzLyd2qnEih42Pq6tlFoxg2sKDurE3Mq0zAsp0C0_8?
emails.subject: From Client to Customer: How a Private Credit COO Thinks About AI

On Fri, Feb 6, 2026 at 1:01‚ÄØAM Jocelyn Ong <Jocelyn_Ong@levinelegalservices.com<mailto:Jocelyn_Ong@levinelegalservices.com>> wrote:
Hi Matthew,
For the budget testing, I‚Äôm tracking two numbers side by side to see how well revenue is converting into cash. These numbers are Invoices booked (accrual) and Cash collected (cash basis).
I‚Äôm including collected during the period even if it relates to prior invoices since budget is funded by cash, not invoice dates. Also, payments from Clio sync to QBO as Undeposited Funds, so they‚Äôre counted as collected even if not yet in the bank (which means regardless of deposit timing). Once deposits are cleared, bank balances will naturally align.
This month, collections were $18,341.62, slightly behind the $20.8k target (88.2%), with $2,811.99 in pending A/R affecting next month. Please refer to the attached report.
I‚Äôll include this in the monthly report‚Äîlet me know your thoughts.
Regards,



Jocelyn Ong
